LTTextBox.text: Historical mapping by RGC Goldfields (1988) and Griffin (1988) support the felsic core
with  mafic-ultramafic  sequences  on  the  flanks,  whilst  Acacia  (1995)  opted  for  a
predominantly ultramafic suite with an areally insignificant felsic core. Reconnaissance
field mapping by Equinox personnel during the 2005 year confirmed a rolling surface to
the felsic block that contains depressions filled with ultramafic. Equinox believes that the
sub-circular  outcrop  of  felsic  units  in  the  anticline  is  physically  connected  to  the
extensive areas of Black Flag Beds to the NW. The Republican Thrust does not extend
as an arrow-straight “tram line” as depicted on the various interpretations of the Cowan
sheet (McIntyre 2004, Griffin 1988, Cooke 2004) in the past, but wraps around what was
a  palaeo-topographical  high  at  the  time  of  thrusting  of  the  mafic-ultramafic  sequence
over Black Flag Beds. The mapping that lead to this solution also implies that the mafic
sequence along the Republican Thrust within E15/148 is very thin (but could thicken to
the  NE),  and  therefore  potential  for  nickel  sulphide  mineralisation  is  limited.  Gravity
profiles  carried  out  on  M15/654  and  extended  on  to  E15/148  could  support  such  an
interpretation, but readers are referred to the discussion under “(B) M15/654” regarding
alternative interpretations of the gravity data.
Notwithstanding  the  interpretation  made  in  the  preceding  paragraph,  MMIM  soil
sampling  was  conducted  along  the  Republican  Thrust  on  a  200m  NS  by  40m  EW
spacing. This resulted in the collection of 168 samples, results for which are presented in
Appendix  1.  These  were  collected  using  a  handheld  GPS  to  +3m  accuracy  and  the
GDA94 datum.
Results  for  nickel,  which  are  up  to  6  times  the  background  value  (25th  percentile
accepted as indicative), appear to be of interest for further work, with 13 attaining levels
that  are  reportedly  indicative  of  cumulate  flow  rock  host.  Several  of  these  are  point
source results (WAA2202, 2210) but the sample spacing is likely the reason, and in the
north  of  the  area,  several  elevated  samples  congregate  along  the  margins  of  a  late
Proterozoic dyke (WAA2092, 2093, 2098). Chromium is elevated for about 10 of these
samples,  but  subdued  for  the  balance  which  is  considered  positive.  However,  copper
values do not support the nickel anomalism, barely achieving two times background. The
most  elevated  Cu  correlate  to  the  lowest  Ni,  and  the  reciprocal  also  holds  true.
Correlations of one element with another show wild scatter rather than coherent support,
except for Co vs Ni, which is to be expected. Field mapping indicates that the area is
extensively lateritised, and in all likelihood several of these nickel anomalies are falsely
elevated in response to lateritisation. Rarely do the elevated Ni values coincide with a
magnetic  feature  of  any  elevation,  except  for  WAA2104,  2179,  2202  and  2210.
Additional limited MMIM work is warranted at a greater density in the areas immediately
around  these  samples  to  ensure  that  potential  targets  are  corroborated  and  better
evaluated,  particularly  in  light  of  the  degree  of  talc  carbonate  development  along  the
leading edge of the upper thrust plate.
5.    WORK PROGRAM 2006
Work recommended for the area in 2006 comprises:
•  M15/654: a focused TEM survey over targets selected by IGS from within the
Acacia data will be undertaken;
•  M15/655  and  654:  drill  testing  of  prospective  targets  within  both  leases  is
proposed;
